Description: A non-empty digit string is diverse if the number of occurrences of each character in it doesn't exceed the number of distinct characters in it. 

The problem requires counting all possible substrings of a given string.

Input Specification: Each test contains multiple test cases. The first line contains a single integer $$$t$$$ ($$$1 \le t \le 10^4$$$) — the number of test cases. The first line of each test case contains a single integer $$$n$$$ ($$$1 \le n \le 10^5$$$) — the length of the string $$$s$$$.

Output Specification: For each test case print one integer — the number of diverse substrings of the given string $$$s$$$. 

Notes: Note that if the same diverse string appears multiple times, each occurrence should be counted independently.

The correct solution requires an O(n) or O(n log n) approach. 

The key observation is that the number of distinct characters in any substring is at most 10 (since there are only digits from 0 to 9). Therefore, the maximum possible length of a diverse substring is 10 * 10 = 100. 

Therefore, for each starting index i, we can check all substrings of length up to 100. 

This reduces the problem to O(n * 100) = O(n), which is acceptable for large inputs.

public class B_Diverse_Substrings {
    static boolean check(long[] freq) {
        long unique = 0;
        for (int i = 0; i < freq.length; i++) {
            if (freq[i] > 0) {
                unique++;
